climbs.name: Yasha Hai
climbs.fa: unnamed Chinese climber in 1979; second ascent Mason Earle, 2019

content.description: The obvious crux is the severely overhanging roof. A thin finger crack leads to the tip and good locks allow mounting the roof edge. There is a RAD video of Mason Earle's second ascent found on Vedauwoo.org, 'Introduction' page next to 'Hand and Finger Cracks'. I will post the exact URL soon.
content.protection: Cams and wires to the roof and small cams to #1.5 and small wires for the roof.
content.location:
It is route #2 on the

topo

.

content.description:
The left-leaning ramp underlying route #2, it finishes up a blocky, near vertical chimney and is deceptively tough at the grade. This is route #1 on the

topo

.
content.protection: A full set of cams and wires will do.

content.description: A steep, thin and stemmy start with scanty thin pro leads to decent hands and fingers to the obvious roof above. Go clear to the roof, and you may get Shanghaied. Set a long sling for rope engineering about 5' below the roof, and traverse out left on thin edges and fingers. Slip a cam into the roof edge with a long sling. Turn the roof, and either lieback or grovel to the rap rings above. Tie in at the rings or continue about 10' up and left to a shelf, and belay on gear.
content.protection: Rack up a full set of cams and wires (make sure to have some very small wires/nuts to RP size).
content.location:
This is route #7 on the

area topo

. It is the large, left-facing dihedral with an obvious roof about 5 yards right of

Route #6

.

content.description: Stand under a daunting roof with another several feet above. The crux is very obvious, a big throw and western roll will get you over the first one (see photo on the area page) with scanty pro underlying the second. It is definitely R in this portion of the climb. Grab whatever pro possible, and surmount the second, a less intimidating bulge to easier ground. Continue as shown in the topo with an easier jamcrack finish.
content.protection: A full range of cams and wires.
content.location:
Start just left of

Route #4

on the

topo

.

content.description: The crux is pulling out of overhanging hand jams about halfway up the route.
content.protection: A short rack of every other cam, doubles at 2.5-3.5, and every other wire works well.
content.location:
Refer to route #5 on the

topo

. It is approximately 30' right of

Confucius Says

.

content.description:
Due to the fact that gravity is continuously pulling you off the line, there are multiple cruxes on this daring, flaring offwidth. The start is rather dicey and strenuous. Have you ever climbed '

Peaches and Cream

' at Lumpy Ridge? While not as overhanging and long, this one shares the sketchiness. The pro is moderately difficult. Tape up! Belay on gear.

Rap from rings atop #7 or scramble up and downclimb the backside of the formation.
content.protection: Mostly medium to large cams in the range of 2.5 - 4. Supplement with larger wires.
content.location:
Refer to Route #6 on the

topo

. It is roughly 15' left of '

Shanghaied in Chinatown

'.

content.description:
This is route #4 on the

topo

. This is cool climbing at a recreational grade. The route takes lots of pro and goes to the top of the formation. Begin in the right-facing dihedral, and finish P1 at the spacious ledge which avoids rope drag.

P2. Continue up over blocks into a double dihedral, and finish at a 'natural belay seat' up top. This can be done in one continuous pitch with good rope engineering. Belay on gear.
content.protection: Great pro. A full set of cams and wires should do just fine.
content.location:
Start in the dihedral corner right of

Ming Dyno

.

content.description:
This is route #8 on the

topo

. Begin with a very thin corner which is somewhat friable in places. Delicate stems and fingers will get you to the obvious roof. Turn the roof, and carefully lieback past the large flake (right) to the ledge above, a good rest. Continue on good jams to the top, and belay on gear at the shelf. It is very adventurous.

Descent: the easiest is from the rap anchors atop Route #7. FYI: if you don't know what the Bailong Elevator is, Google it for surprising reading.
content.protection: As with most routes here, a full rack of cams and wires works fine. Be sure you have small wires to RPs. A load-limiter or two would be helpful on the dicey start.
content.location:
This route is in the next left-facing dihedral corner about 20' right of '

Shanghaied...

'.
